review_title: Beautiful campus, IT department lacks professionalism and leadership
job_title: Audio Visual Technician in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Very nice campus, and if you're not a minority, you will excel with little to know effort at the organization, without management fearing your abilities and competency.
cons: The IT department will work you like a slave and refuse to pay you your worth and your competency. They keep the money only for a particular department that has so called "programmers", yet they have never created any application. they "programmers" simply manage already built programs from third parties, and if there are issues with the program they simply contact the vendor to fix it. Other than having that particular group as their favorite to pool money into, upper management enjoys the bulk of the budget, fattening their pockets and living a grand lifestyle, while their hardest working team (Networking and Help Desk) get below national average pay. They enjoy having their whole infrastructure redone, refreshed, upgraded, redesigned, and maintained well for next to no expenditure on their engineers. They benefited off working their network team like slaves while paying them next to nothing. They've even ostracized their network team by removing them from the building where the whole IT department is, and put them in a completely different building to be forgotten about. They will smile in your face, say nice things to your face, even pay for your lunch once in a while (which is pennies when you're making well over six figures a year), but truly they look at talented, hard working individuals as a threat. They have a clique coined the "Mafia", which, if you're not part of, consider yourself just a peon. It's unfortunate how they treat their most talented employees there in the IT department. This is the reason why 3/5 of their engineers up and left recently, and several others in other departments. If you are a minority, and talented, I strongly suggest you steer clear of this particular department at FGCU; they will view you as less than and drain you of all of your energy by working you hard and choosing not to pay you your worth. Almost all of the minorities at FGCU's BTS department quit because management refused to pay them their worth, and or refused to give them the position that they worked hard to try to achieve; this is not an exaggeration, so take it however you want, I'm just being transparent and trying to save other minorities from going through what the rest have been through. They show no remorse, nor professionalism; their motto is, if you leave we'll just replace you. What they don't seem to understand is that, it's not easy to replace talent. They will soon learn though. Otherwise, I enjoyed my time working for the organization as a whole, I gave it my whole heart and effort, I really looked forward to helping them move forward technical wise, but I realize BTS did not see my worth and value, and they disregarded all of the efforts, late nights, coming in on my off days, drenched clothes from working in many non HVAC IDFs, willingness to help any time and in any way that I could, completed every single project they gave me with little to no issues, etc. It's a truly disappointing situation that I experienced there, I never worked for such greedy management who seek to compensate certain groups that they favor, and overlook the group that would have the most vital part of helping the organization move forward in the digital age. Upper management is known for making promises to your face, and going against their word once the conversation is done. Lack of professionalism would be an understatement. I would never consider working for the management I worked for over there ever in my life; I do however enjoyed working for FGCU as a whole.

Small class sizes allow for personal relationships with students. Managment (deans) seem to be in touch with their schools exceptionally well, and advocate for their staff well.
cons: Parking, funding, low expectations of students academically, few food choices on campus.  Diversity is not encouraged as much I would have expected on a university campus, but we are in the south and that must be considered.  Really there is not much to complain about.

review_title: Look elsewhere for employment while in grad school ... or look elsewhere for grad school.
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Fort Myers, FL
pros:
Beautiful campus.
Friendly and helpful staff.
Spirit of community.
Incredible growth. 

I enjoy working here. The work itself is very rewarding and the students are generally good to work with.
cons:
Low pay and compensation. I have a bachelors degree and work two jobs on campus. One is salary based per course, the other is hourly. When I do my job privately, I can make upwards of $60-75 per hour. On campus I make $11 per hour. I have no benefits, paid time off, or sick leave. 

Constant restructuring. The university is new (started in the late nineties) and is constantly changing due to growth, but also due to state budget cutbacks. A few years ago I was hired for a full time job with an office, and nearly double my previous salary, then two semesters later they eliminated the position title due to budget cuts and combined it with some others and gave that job to a long time employee. I was forced to resume my old position, and my old salary. Thee will not create new positions despite needs because of budget limitations. 

Nepotism, hand waving. Jobs go to and are retained by the in-crowd. In my dept, there are two people working in positions that should go to graduate student teachers (full time, with full benefits including tuition deferment) that have been there for 8+ years ... in a masters' degree program. I have been told on more than one occasion in regards to pay or working regulations "well, the policy is _____, but we'll see what we can do for you for now." 

Ineffective Management. When I complain about these things to my immediate supervisor or department head, the usual response is "it comes from _____'s office, there's really nothing we can do about it." I've been there for 4 years and I've never had a performance review. At one point I was told there had been a complaint against me only after I asked why my hours had been cut back. 

Lack of support and tools, inconsistency. I don't have the tools I need to do my job effectively. I can't get access to those tools because of budget limitations. Some departments have huge budgets and facilities. The Engineering department has huge labs, workshops, and tools for students to work with. The students in my department don't even have access to the software and computers they need.

review_title: FGCU is a place where most people come to work when they are already retired resulting in lazy performance.
job_title: Assistant Professor in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Lower expectations for performance compared to other universities. If you plan correctly, you can show up for work do your job and go home without being bothered.
cons: The no tenure approach allows professors to stay employed despite lack of performance. There are many professors who are there to get an extra easy income while collected their retirement pay from previous jobs. The retirement attitude reflects in the work productivity of many professors.

job_title: Undergraduate Admissions Representative/Student Caller in Fort Myers, FL
pros: If you live on campus and would like to work with admissions, being a student caller at the call center for the semester based campaigns is a great opportunity. Hours are flexible for students and management is very understanding. Pay was appropriate for the job duties.
cons: Obviously there are no insurance benefits for this part-time/temporary position. It does not seem easy to find a related position in the office for students.

job_title: Faculty in Fort Myers, FL
pros: The undergraduate teaching is still the focus which I believe it is fair to students. The work-life balance is great! Faculty and staff enjoys free access to the aquatics center and gym.
cons: The support departments (IT, Canvas, legal, etc.) need to really have a good attitude.  They have a job because of the school is in a teaching business. Their job is to make teaching easier, not to make their own job easier.

job_title: IT Technician in Fort Myers, FL
pros:
a lot of time off 
people are nice 
medical is great
cons:
pay isn't very good 
only the top management get payed well and look out for each other
kiss up to people if you want to get head, doesn't matter about skill

job_title: in Lake Worth, FL
pros: Best management group I have ever worked for. Clearly state and measure goals, great working environment.  Teams working together creates positive and successful results.
cons: State education budget continues to force changes.  Budget review and decisions force business  actions that can be detrimental effectiveness of staff.

job_title: Administrative in Fort Myers, FL
pros:
Good medical/ benefits
Decent paid time off... if your supervisor/VP allows you to take it
cons: Administration runs a toxic and abusive work environment. When you try to report it, you will be attacked and then the cover-up scheme rolls into place. There's a reason the university has a ridiculously high employee turnover rate.  FGCU was a place that had so much potential, but will continue down the downward spiral until a few 'founding employees' are shown the door.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Myers, FL
pros:
-Awesome benefit options (though they have been dropping lately due to the governor.)
-Really nice staff
-Easy to meet people and make friendships
cons:
-No real room for growth. I had to switch departments in order to move from Part-time to Full-time, and know I will have to do it again if I ever want to get a better job.
-Very widespread acceptance of a "good old boys" mentality wherein open positions will be posted but then rigged to be given to friends. I lost out on a position once because another person running for it had known the people on the hiring committee for years before I'd even started working here (despite the job requirements listing the need for a degree that I had and she did not.)
-No promotions unless someone quits, because they don't fund new positions.
-The university also doesn't fund promotions (even if you aren't being replaced) OR raises. The only time I've had a raise in my salary was when the governor took out 3% more of our pay for retirement and the school was nice enough to give everyone a 2% raise to help compensate. (I'll give them that, as it was a very nice gesture that they did not have to make.)
-President makes over $300,000 and gets a raise worth twice my salary each year, and they won't give anyone who isn't a director or dean a raise. We don't even get a Christmas bonus or anything. We even had to fire a lot of part-time workers this year because of state budget cuts, but his raise alone could have saved at least half of those jobs.
-Workers are paid below the standard for their chosen field in some departments. There is also a wide gap between faculty pay. Some faculty barely make $350,000 while others are paid over $100,000. No tenure also makes it hard for many to accept such low pay for their skills.

*********Half the school is run by workers who are not students, some even in their 40s and 50s, who are stuck as part-time employees without benefits, who work full-time hours, and they will never see their positions made full-time. They get paid less than full-time workers and are never offered benefits, regardless of how long they hold these positions. Beware the job classification OPS. It means you will be a part-time, hourly employee with no benefits, no sick leave, no vacation time, and essentially no future.

job_title: Instructor Mathematics in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Great department within the College of Arts and Sciences. Colleagues communicate well with, and are supportive of, each other.
cons: Department member offices are scattered across the campus, which doesn't promote as much unity as there could be.

job_title: Supervisory Support Staff in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Benefits, insurance, vacation time, tuition assistance are the biggest advantages available. Pay is also good. For the most part it is a great place to work.
cons: Politics of the various departments and learning to play the games. It is difficult to do your job when you are trying to determine what to say and how to say it.

job_title: Alta Resources in Fort Myers, FL
pros: It is a great opportunity to work at while you are studying because they are flexible with your schedule. The work load is manageable and sometimes it allows you to study for exams.
cons: I really would not say there are cons for working here. If anything I think it is beneficial in many ways. It allows students to get work experience while making some money.

review_title: Good college job but is dead end
job_title: Personal Trainer in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Flexible schedule, good clients, rewarding, good environment, fun staff, able to teach group fitness as well, you make your own schedule, you are your own boss
cons: Not enough pay , no incentives to sell, managers never actually there for fitness, high manager and employee turnover, there is a pay cap of 13 dollars

review_title: A little disorganized, but love the people.
job_title: Administrative Specialist in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Great culture, great people, esp. if you work for a department in the humanities (but of course I am biased).
cons: A little disorganized on the administrative level. As an administrative specialist, I received a bit of confusing and contradictory information about procedures and rules. Things are constantly changing in order to fit state regulations.

job_title: Administrative Specialist in Fort Myers, FL
pros: FGCU has a good work environment. Faculty and staff are all helpful and kind. Of course there are the bad apples here and there but overall an excellent place to work.
cons: You have to pay an annual fee for parking of at least almost $100 for unassigned parking on campus (over $500/year for a reserved spot)

review_title: Excellent place to work and study.
job_title: in Fort Myers, FL
pros: FGCU is located in beautiful Fort Myers, FL. FGCU is an up-and-coming University, and will surely grow into a prestigious school.
cons: There are no real cons to working for FGCU. Parking has been an issue in the past, so you may have to walk a little ways before reaching your office.

job_title: Lab Assistant in Fort Myers, FL
pros: There are people that are there that want nothing more than for you to succeed. The opportunities that present themselves are amazing, and if that isn't enough for you then you can present your own ideas and work on them.
cons: You must be a self-starter and be willing to do your own research.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Good location, friendly people, casual atmosphere, easy parking, easy to find lunch. Colleagues were friendly and helpful, shared ideas easily. Many students were enjoyable to be around.
cons: Many students do not care to actually learn, but that could be an issue of this generation. Inconsistent experience depending on which professor you teach for.

job_title: Communications Manager in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Working at FGCU was a great experience. The ability to connect with the administration and broader community were valuable experiences.
cons: I don't really feel as though there were many cons experiences. However, at times, scheduling seemed to be terrible.

review_title: Excellent! Very willing to work with my school schedule. Allowed me to always be flexible! Also always good coworkers

review_title: Great experience, get as much time in the field as possible.
